original: Pañcādīhi cuddasahi saṅkhyāhi yonaṃ ṭo hoti-pañca, pañca.🔽Pañcādīnaṃ cuddasannama.
analyzed: pañca ādīhi saṅkhyāhi ṭaḥ pañca  pañca ādīnam cud dasan nama
translated: I am the sva of the five and so on up to the fourteen.🔽I am the sva of the five and so on up to the fourteen.🔽I am the sva of the five and so on up to the fourteen.🔽I am the sva of the five and so on up to the fourteen.🔽I am the sva of the five and so on up to the fourteen.🔽I am the sva of the five and so on up to the fourteen.🔽I am the sva of the five and so on up to the fourteen.🔽I am the sva of the five and so on up to the fourteen.🔽I am the sva of the five and so on up to the fourteen.🔽I am the sva of the five and so on up to the fourteen.🔽I am the sva of the five and so on up to the fourteen.🔽I am the sva of the five and so on up to the fourteen.🔽I am the sva of the five and so on up to the fourteen.

original: Pañcādīnaṃ cuddasannaṃ sunaṃhisva hoti-ettāpavādoyaṃ-pañcahi pañcabhi, pañcantaṃ
analyzed: pañca ādīnam hoti etta apavādaḥ yam pañcahi pañcabhi pañcantam
translated: I am the sva of the five and so on up to the fourteen.🔽I am the sva of the five and so on up to the fourteen.🔽I am the sva of the five and so on up to the fourteen.🔽I am the sva of the five and so on up to the fourteen.🔽I am the sva of the five and so on up to the fourteen.🔽I am the sva of the five and so on up to the fourteen.

original: pañcasu-evaṃ chādayo aṭṭhārasantā-eko ca da sa cāti catthasamāse ekena adhikā dasāti🔽tatiyāsamāse vā kate “ekatthatāya”nti vibhattilopo-evamupari ca.
analyzed: pañcasu evam cha ādayaḥ ca sa ca ati cattha samāse ekena adhikāḥ dasa ati  tatiyā samāse vā kate vibhatti lopaḥ evam upari ca
translated: I am the sva of the five and so on up to the fourteen.

original: Ekaṭṭhānamā.🔽Ekaaṭṭhānaṃ ā hoti dase pare.🔽Ra saṅdhyāto vā.
analyzed: ekaṭṭhānamā 🔽ekaaṭṭhānam ā hoti dase pare 🔽ra saṅdhyāyāḥ vā
translated: I am the

original: Saṅkhyāto parassa dasassa ra hoti vibhāsā-saca“pañcamiyaṃ parasse”ti anuvattamāne “ādissā“ti dakārasseva hoti-ekā rasa, ekādasa.
analyzed: saṅkhyātaḥ parassa dasassa ra hoti vibhāsā saca pañcamiyam parassa iti anuvattamāne ādissa ati dakārassa iva hoti ekāḥ rase ekādasa
translated: The sign ra is added to the number ten of another, and also the sign sa, “When the fifth of another” is repeated, “after the vowel” is only of the vowel da.

original: Ā saṅkhyāyāsatādo’naññatthe.
analyzed: ā saṅkhyā yā sa tā da ūnañña tthe
translated: Ā is added to the number after sat, when it is not a different meaning.

original: Saṅkhyāyamuttarapade dvissa ā hotasatādo’naññatthe-dvādasa.
analyzed: saṅkhyā yam uttara pade dvis saḥ ā ha u tasa tāda ūna aññatthe dvādasa
translated: After the number, ā is added to dvīsa, after sat, when it is not a different meaning.

original: Khā cattāḷīsādo.
analyzed: khā
translated: Khā is added to cattālīsa.

original: Dvissa khā vā hotacattāḷīsādo’naññatthe-bārasa.
analyzed: dvissa khā vā
translated: Khā is added to dvīsa, after cattālīsa, when it is not a different meaning.

original: Tisse.
analyzed: tisse
translated: Tīsa is added to dvīsa.

original: Saṅkhyāyamuttarapade tissa e hotasatādo’naññatthe.🔽Chatīhi ḷo ca.🔽Chatihi parassa dasassa ḷo hoti ro ca-teḷasa-terasa.
analyzed: saṅkhyā yam uttara pade tissaḥ e hota sata āda ūnaññatthe  chatīhi ḷo ca  chatihi parassa dasassa ḷaḥ hoti raḥ ca ti ḷasa te rasa
translated: After the number, e is added to tīsa, after sat, when it is not a different meaning.🔽ḷo and ro are added to chattiṃsa.🔽ḷo and ro are added to the number ten of another, after chattiṃsa.

original: Catussa cuco honti vā dasasadde pare-dvitte-cuddasa coddasa catuddasa.🔽Vīsatidasesu pañcassa paṇṇupaṇṇā.
analyzed: catussa cucaḥ honti vā dasa sadde coddasa catuddasa  vīsatidasesu pañcassa paṇṇupaṇṇā
translated: Cuco is added to catussa, after dasa, when it is not a different meaning.🔽Paṇṇu and paṇṇā are added to pañcassa, after vīsa and tiṃsa.

original: Vīsatidasesu paresu pañcassa paṇṇupaṇṇā honti vā yathākkamaṃ-paṇṇarasa pañcadasa.
analyzed: vīsatidasesu paresu pañcassa paṇṇupaṇṇāḥ honti vā pañcadasa
translated: Paṇṇu and paṇṇā are added to pañcassa, after the other vīsa and tiṃsa, respectively.

original: Chasasa so.
analyzed: chasasa saḥ
translated: So is added to cha and asa.

original: Chassa so iccayamādeso hoti dasasadde pare-soḷasa sorasa, sattarasa sattadasa, aṭṭhārasa aṭṭhādasa-ekena ūnā vīsatīti visesanasamāsagabbhe tatiyāsamāse.
analyzed: chassa saḥ i t ca ayam ādesaḥ hoti dasa sadde pare soḷasa sorasa sattarasa sattadasa aṭṭhārasa aṭṭhādasa ekena ūnā vīsatī iti visesana samāsa gabbhe tatiyā samāse
translated: The word dasa (ten) becomes dasa in the following sixteen cases when the word dasa is followed by another word: soḷasa (sixteen), sattarasa (seventeen), aṭṭhārasa (eighteen), vīsa (twenty), with the exception of ekūna (nineteen).

original: Itthiyamhāsitapumitthi pumevekatthe.
analyzed: itthi yam hā sita pum itthi pum eva ekatthe
translated: The feminine form of a word is used for a masculine word in the same sense.

original: Itthiyaṃ vattamāne ekatthe samānādhikaraṇe uttarapade pare bhāsitapumitthi pumeva
analyzed: itthiyam vattamāne ekatthe samāna adhikaraṇe uttara pade pare bhāsita pum itthi pum eva
translated: When a word in the feminine form is used for a masculine word in the same sense, that is, when the same case-ending is used for both words,

original: hotīti pumbhāvā āppaccayo nivattate-ekūnavīsati-itthiliṅgekavacananto-vīsatiādayo
analyzed: hoti iti pumbhāvā āp paccayaḥ
translated: the masculine form is dropped. The feminine form is used for the following words: ekūnavīsati (nineteen), itthiliṅgekavacananto (feminine singular ending), vīsa (twenty),🔽ānavuti (ninety), ekavacananto (singular ending), itthiliṅga (feminine gender).

original: hi ānavutiyā ekavacanantā itthiliṅgā-(bho) ekūnavīsati ekūnavīsatimiccādi-evaṃ vīsati
analyzed: hi ānavutiyāḥ ekavacana antāḥ itthi liṅga ābho ekūnavīsati vīsati
translated: The following words are formed: (bho) ekūnavīsati, ekūnavīsatim, etc. In the same way, vīsa (twenty),

original: ekavīsati dvāvīsati bāvīsati tevīsatippabhutayo.
analyzed: ekavīsati dvāvīsati bāvīsati tevīsati pabhutayaḥ
translated: ekavīsati (twenty-one), dvāvīsati (twenty-two), bāvīsati (twenty-three), tevīsati (twenty-four), etc. are formed.

original: Vīsatayaṃ pañcassa vā paṇṇaādese-paṇṇuvīsati, pañcavīsati-ekena ūnā tiṃsati tiṃsā
analyzed: vīsatayam pañcassa vā pañcavīsati ekena ūnā tiṃsati tiṃsā
translated: In the case of vīsatayaṃ (twenty), the following words are formed: pañcassa vā paṇṇaādese (in the case of five, etc., in the sense of leaves, etc.), paṇṇuvīsati (twenty leaves), pañcavīsati (twenty-five), ekuna (nineteen), tiṃsati (thirty),

original: vā ekunatiṃsati ekunatiṃsā-matikaññā samā-evaṃ tiṃsati tiṃsāppabhutayo-tiṃsāsaddassa
analyzed: vā ekunatiṃsati samā evam tiṃsati
translated: tiṃsā (thirty), ekunatiṃsati (twenty-nine), ekunatiṃsā (twenty-nine), matikaññā (thirty-one), samā (thirty-two), tiṃsati (thirty), tiṃsā (thirty), etc. are formed.

original: pana silope-dīgharassāti yogavibhāgā rasse-tiṃsa-niggahītāgame ca tiṃsantipi hoti-evamupari
analyzed: pana si lope dīgha rassā ti yogavibhāgāḥ ca hoti evam upari
translated: but in silope, in dīgharaṃsa, and in rasse tiṃsa niggahītāgame, tiṃsa also is. Thus above

original: ca yathāsambhavaṃ-dvattiṃsatiādinaṃ rassañcattāni-cattāḷīsāya samhi-cattāḷīsā cattāḷīsa
analyzed: ca yathāsambhavam dvattiṃsati ādinam samhi cattāḷīsā cattāḷīsa
translated: and in accordance with the context, in dvattīsa, etc., and in rasse cattāni, cattāḷīsāya samhi, cattāḷīsā, cattāḷīsa

original: cattāḷīsaṃ vā,evaṃ cattārīsā cattārisa cattārīsaṃ.
analyzed: cattāḷīsam vā evam cattārīsā cattārisa cattārīsam
translated: or cattāḷīsaṃ.

original: Dvissā ca.
analyzed: dvissā ca
translated: And in dvīsa.

original: Asatādo’naññatthe cattāḷīsādo dvissa e hoti vā ā ca-dve cattāḷīsa dvācattāḷīsa dvīcattāḷīsa-evaṃ
analyzed: asata ādo naññatthe cattāḷīsa ādaḥ dvissaḥ e hoti vā ā ca dve cattāḷīsa dvācattāḷīsa dvīcattāḷīsa evam
translated: In asatā, in anaññatthe, in cattāḷīsā, e is or ā is added to dvīsa-dve cattāḷīsa, dvācattāḷīsa, dvīcattāḷīsa. Thus

original: dvevattārisa dvācattārīsa dvicattārīsa, dvecattāḷīsati dvācattāḷīsati dvicattāḷīsati.
analyzed: dvevattārisa dvācattārīsa dvicattārīsa dvecattāḷīsati dvācattāḷīsati dvicattāḷīsati
translated: dve cattāḷīsa, dvācattāḷīsa, dvicattāḷīsa, dvecattāḷīsati, dvācattāḷīsati, dvicattāḷīsati.

original: Cattāḷīsādo vā.
analyzed: cattāḷīsādaḥ vā
translated: Or in cattāḷīsā.

original: Asatādo’naññatthe cattāḷīsādo tisse vā hoti-tecattāḷīsa tivattāḷīsa tecattāḷīsati
analyzed: asata ādo naññatthe cattāḷīsa ādaḥ tisse vā hoti tecattāḷīsa tivattāḷīsa tecattāḷīsati
translated: In asatā, in anaññatthe, in cattāḷīsā, tisse is added-tecattāḷīsa, tivattāḷīsa, tecattāḷīsati

original: ticattāḷīsati-tecattārīsa ticattārīsa-dvepaññāsa dvāpaññāsa dvipaññāsa dvepaṇṇāsati
analyzed: ticattāḷīsa titecattārīsa ticattārīsa dvepaññāsa dvāpaññāsa dvipaññāsa dvepaṇṇāsati
translated: tecattārīsa, ticattārīsa, dvepaññāsa, dvāpaññāsa, dvipaññāsa, dvepaṇṇāsati

original: paṇṇāsa, dvesaṭṭhi dvāsaṭṭhi dvisaṭṭhi, tesaṭṭhi tisaṭṭhi, dvesattati dvā sattati
analyzed: paṇṇāsa dvesaṭṭhi dvāsaṭṭhi dvisaṭṭhi tesaṭṭhi tisaṭṭhi dvesattati dvā sattati
translated: paṇṇāsa, dvesaṭṭhi, dvāsaṭṭhi, dvisaṭṭhi, tesaṭṭhi, tisaṭṭhi, dvesattati, dvā sattati

original: dvīsattati dvesattari dvāsattari dvisattari, tesattati tisattati tesattari tisattari,
analyzed: dvīsattati dvesattari dvāsattari dvisattari tesattati tisattati tesattari tisattari
translated: seventy-two, seventy-two, seventy-two, seventy-two, thirty-seven, thirty-seven, thirty-seven, thirty-seven,🔽eighty-two, eighty-two, eighty-two, eighty-two, eighty-three, eighty-three, eighty-three, eighty-three,

original: dvñasīti dvāasīti dvīyāsīti-yāgamo-tñasīti tiyāsīti, dvenavuti dvānavuti dvinavuti,
analyzed: dvñasi iti dvāasi iti dvīyā asi itiyāgamotñasi iti tiyā asi iti dve navuti dvā navuti dvi navuti
translated: ninety-two, ninety-two, ninety-two, ninety-two, ninety-three, ninety-three, ninety-three, ninety-three,🔽one hundred, one hundred, one hundred, one hundred, one hundred, one hundred, one hundred, one hundred,

original: tenavuti tinavuti-sataṃ, napuṃsaka mekavacanantaṃ-evaṃ sahassadayo-koṭi pakoṭi koṭippakoṭi🔽akkhohiṇiyo itthiliṅgekavacanantā-vaggabhede tu sabbāsampi saṅkhyānaṃ bahuvacanañca
analyzed: tenavuti tinavuti satam napuṃsakam eka vacana antam evam  itthi liṅga ekavacana anta vagga bhede tu sabbāsam pi saṅkhyānam bahuvacanam ca
translated: one thousand, one thousand, one thousand, one thousand, one thousand, one thousand, one thousand, one thousand,🔽one hundred thousand, one hundred thousand, one hundred thousand, one hundred thousand, one hundred thousand, one hundred thousand, one hundred thousand, one hundred thousand,🔽one million, one million, one million, one million, one million, one million, one million, one million,

original: hoteva-yathā-dve visatiyo, tisso vīsatiyo iccādi-dasa asakaṃ sataṃ nāma,dasasataṃ
analyzed: visatiyaḥ tissaḥ vīsatiyaḥ iti ādi dasa asakam satam nāma dasa satam
translated: ten million, ten million, ten million, ten million, ten million, ten million, ten million, ten million,🔽one hundred million, one hundred million, one hundred million, one hundred million, one hundred million, one hundred million, one hundred million, one hundred million,🔽one billion, one billion, one billion, one billion, one billion, one billion, one billion, one billion,🔽one hundred billion, one hundred billion, one hundred billion, one hundred billion, one hundred billion, one hundred billion, one hundred billion, one hundred billion,🔽one trillion, one trillion, one trillion, one trillion, one trillion, one trillion, one trillion, one trillion,

original: sahassaṃ, dasasahassaṃ nahutaṃ, dasanahutaṃ lakkhaṃ, satasahassantipi vuccati-lakkhasataṃ
analyzed: sahassam dasa sahassam nahutam dasa nahutam lakkham sata sahassam ti pi vuccati lakkha satam
translated: one hundred trillion, one hundred trillion, one hundred trillion, one hundred trillion, one hundred trillion, one hundred trillion, one hundred trillion, one hundred trillion,

original: koṭi, koṭilakkhasataṃ pakoṭi, pakoṭilakkhasataṃ koṭippakoṭi-evaṃ nahutaṃ ninnahutaṃ🔽akkhohiṇī bindu abbudaṃ nirabbudaṃ ahakahaṃ ababaṃ aṭaṭaṃ sogandhikaṃ uppalaṃ kumudaṃ
analyzed: koṭi koṭi lakkha satam pakoṭi pakoṭi lakkha satam koṭi ppakoṭi evam nahutam ninna hutam 🔽akkhohiṇī bindu abbudam nirabbudam ahakaham ababam aṭaṭam sogandhikam uppalam kumudam
translated: one quadrillion, one quadrillion, one quadrillion, one quadrillion, one quadrillion, one quadrillion, one quadrillion, one quadrillion,🔽one sextillion, one sextillion, one sextillion, one sextillion, one sextillion, one sextillion, one sextillion, one sextillion,🔽one septillion, one septillion, one septillion, one septillion, one septillion, one septillion, one septillion, one septillion,🔽one octillion, one octillion, one octillion

original: puṇḍarikaṃ padumaṃ kathānaṃ mahākathānaṃ asaṅkheyyanti yathākkamaṃ satalakkhaguṇaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: puṇḍarikam padumam kathānam mahā kathānam asaṅkheyyam ti yathākkamam sata lakkha guṇam veditabbam
translated: The lotus, the water lily, the story, the great story, the incalculable, should be known in order as having a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand, an incalculable characteristic.

original: Athāsaṅkhyamuccate.
analyzed: atha asaṅkhyam uccate
translated: Now the incalculable is stated.🔽It is twofold, according to the division of the foot, etc. Herein,

original: Taṃ duvidhaṃ pādicādibhedena-tattha-pa parā apa saṃ anu ava o ni du vi adhi api ati
analyzed: tam duvidham parā apa sam anu ava o ni du vi adhi api ati
translated: pa, parā, apa, saṃ, anu, ava, o, ni, du, vi, adhi, api, ati,🔽su, u, abhi, pati, pari, upa, ā—these are the twenty feet.

original: su u abhi pati pari upa ā-ime vīsati pādayo-cādayo pana-ca vā ha aha eva evamiccādayo-ime
analyzed: su u abhi pati pari upa āime vīsati vīsati vā ha aha eva evam icca ādayoime
translated: But cā, vā, ha, aha, eva, evaṃ, icchā, etc.,🔽these two are devoid of gender and number.

original: dvepi liṅgasaṅkhyārahitā-etehi pana yathāsambhavaṃ vihitānaṃ vibhattinaṃ.
analyzed: dve api yathāsambhavam
translated: But by these, as the case may be, the endings are formed.

original: Asaṅkhyehi sabbāsaṃ.
analyzed: asaṅkhyehi sabbāsam
translated: With the incalculable, of all🔽the endings,🔽for the incalculable is not found.

original: Avijjamānasaṅkhyohi parāsaṃ sabbāsaṃ vibhattīnaṃ lopo hotīti lopo ca.
analyzed: a vijjamāna saṅkhyaḥ hi parāsam sabbāsam vibhattīnam lopaḥ hoti iti lopaḥ ca
translated: The elision of all the endings is called elision.🔽And the difference after the ending is like that in the case of the neuter, etc.

original: Vibhattiyā tato bhedo saliṅgānaṃ bhave tathā tumhādinaṃ tvaliṅgesu nevatthi pādivādinaṃ.
analyzed: vibhattiyā tatas bhedaḥ sa liṅgānam bhave tathā tumha ādinam tu aliṅgesu na iva atthi pādi vādinam
translated: But in the case of the feminine, etc., there is none.

original: Vutatāni syādyantāni.
analyzed: vu ta tāni sya ādi antāni
translated: The stated ones end in syā.🔽Now the single word is stated.

original: Athekatthamuccate-upasaddā paṭhamekavacanaṃ si-tassa “asaṅkhyehi sabbāsaṃ”ti lopo-kumbhasaddā
analyzed: paṭhama ekavacanam sitassa asaṅkhyehi lopaḥ kumbha saddā
translated: The first singular is si. The elision of all the endings with the incalculable is by the rule. The word kumbha

original: chaṭṭhayekavacanaṃ sa-upa kuma asa iti ṭhite “aviggabho niccasamāso padantaraviggaho
analyzed: chaṭṭhayā ekavacanam sa upa kuma asaḥ iti ṭhite aviggabhaḥ nicca samāsaḥ pada antara viggaho
translated: The sixth case in the singular is sa-upa, kuma, asa. When the words are thus placed, “The compound is invariable, the separation of the words is by the word ‘ve’🔽(and) ‘samīpaṃ kumbhasse’ (is) the separation of the words.”

original: ve”ti samīpaṃ kumbhasseti padantaraciggahe-“syādi syādinekattha”nti sabbatthekatthe vattate.
analyzed: vā iti samīpam kumbhassa iti sya ādinā ekattham vattate
translated: “Syādi syādinekattha” (is) used in all cases where there is one meaning.

original: Asaṅkhyaṃ vibhatti sampatti samipa sākalyāhāva yathāpacchā yugapadatthe.
analyzed: asaṅkhyam vibhatti sampatti samipa sākalya āhāva yathāpacchā yugapad atthe
translated: “Asaṅkhyaṃ vibhatti sampatti samipa sākalyāhāva yathāpacchā yugapadatthe.”

original: Asaṅkhyaṃ syādyantaṃ vibhattyādinamatthevattamānaṃ syādyantena sahekatthambhavati.
analyzed: asaṅkhyam syādi antam syādi antena saha ikattham bhavati
translated: “Asaṅkhyaṃ syādyantaṃ vibhattyādinamatthevattamānaṃ syādyantena sahekatthambhavati.”

original: Ekatthatāyaṃ.
analyzed: ekatthatā ayam
translated: “Ekatthatāyaṃ.”🔽“Īyādiṇadisamāsehi ekatthibhāvo ekatthatā-tasmiṃ syādi lopo hoti.”

original: Īyādiṇadisamāsehi ekatthibhāvo ekatthatā-tasmiṃ syādi lopo hoti-“taṃ napuṃsaka”mitinapuṃsakaliṅgaṃ-tato syādi-“pubbasmāmādito”ti lope sampatte.
analyzed: īyādi ṇadi samāsehi ekatthi bhāvaḥ ekattha tā tasmin syādi lopaḥ hoti tam napuṃsakam iti napuṃsaka liṅgam tatas lope sampatte
translated: “Taṃ napuṃsaka” (is) the neuter gender.

original: Nāto mapañcamiyā.
analyzed: na a taḥ ma pañcamiyā
translated: “Nāto mapañcamiyā.”

original: Amādekatthā pubbaṃ yadekatthamakārantaṃ tato parāsaṃ sabbāsaṃ vibhattīnaṃ lopo na
analyzed: amāt ekatthā pubbam yat ekattham akāra antam tatas parāsam sabbāsam vibhattīnam lopaḥ na
translated: “Amādekatthā pubbaṃ yadekatthamakārantaṃ tato parāsaṃ sabbāsaṃ vibhattīnaṃ lopo na🔽hoti aṃtu bhavatyapañcamiyā.”

original: hoti aṃtu bhavatyapañcamiyā-upakumbhaṃ tiṭṭhati-kumbhassa samīpaṃ tiṭṭhatīti attho-upakumbhaṃ pakassa.
analyzed: hoti bhavati a pañcamiyā upakumbham tiṭṭhati kumbhassa samīpam tiṭṭhati iti attho upakumbham pakassa
translated: “Upakumbhaṃ tiṭṭhati-kumbhassa samīpaṃ tiṭṭhatīti attho-upakumbhaṃ pakassa.”

original: Vā tatiyāsattamīnaṃ.🔽Amādekatthā pubbaṃ yadekatthamakārantaṃ tato parāsaṃ tatiyā sattamīnaṃ aṃ hoti vā-upakumbhaṃ🔽kataṃ, upakumbhena vā, upa kumbhaṃ dehi-pañcamiyaṃ amabhāvā-upakumbhā apehi-upakumbhamāyattaṃ-upakumbhaṃ
analyzed: vā tatiyā sattamīnam  amāt ekatthā pubbam yat ekattham akāra antam tatas parāsam tatiyā sattamīnam aṃ hoti vā upakumbham  katam upakumbhena vai upa kumbham apehi upakumbham āyattam upakumbham
translated: Or after the third and seventh.

original: nīdhehi, upakumbhe vā-evamupanagaramiccādi-samīpaṃ agginoupaggi-etthapana-“pubbasmāmādito”ti
analyzed: upa kumbhe vā evam upanagaram icca ādi samīpam aggino upaggi ittha pana pubba sma āma āditas ti
translated: After the first, when the first is of the same meaning as the second, and the second is not a verb, the third and seventh are aṃ or u. upakumbhaṃ kataṃ, upakumbhena vā, upa kumbhaṃ dehi. In the fifth, because of the absence of aṃ, upakumbhā apehi. upakumbhamāyattaṃ, upakumbhaṃ nīdhehi, upakumbhe vā. Thus upagāram, etc. upagga, near the fire. Here, “after the first, etc.”

original: sabbasyādi lopova-evamupaguru-veti sabbattha vattate.
analyzed: sabbasya ādi sabbattha vattate
translated: All beginnings, like lopa, thus upaguru. Thus it occurs everywhere.

original: Amādi.🔽Amādi syādyantaṃ syādyantena saha bahulamekatthaṃ hoti-gāmaṃ gato gāmagato, muhuttaṃ🔽sukhaṃ muhuttasukhaṃ-vuttiyevopapadasa māse-kumbhakāro, ettha bahulādhikārā asyādyantenāpi
analyzed: am ādi  am ādi syādi antam syādi antena saha bahulam ekattham hoti gāmam gataḥ gāma gataḥ muhuttam  sukham bahula adhikārāḥ asya ādi antena api
translated: After the first, etc.

original: samāso. Ntamānaktavantūhi vākya-dhammaṃ suṇanto, dhammaṃ suṇamāno, odanaṃ bhuttavā,
analyzed: vākya dhammam suṇantaḥ dhammam suṇamānaḥ odanam bhuttavā
translated: After the first, etc., is often of the same meaning as the last, etc. gāmaṃ gato, gāmagato. muhuttaṃ sukhaṃ, muhuttasukhaṃ. In the fifth, because of the absence of aṃ, kumbhakāro. Here, because of the frequent occurrence, the compound is also with the first and last. Ntamānaktavantūhi vākya-dhammaṃ suṇanto, dhammaṃ suṇamāno, odanaṃ bhuttavā,

original: rañgñā bhato rājahato, asinā jinno asicchinno, pitarāsadisopitusadiso, dadhinā upasittaṃ
analyzed: rañgñā bhataḥ rāja hataḥ asinā jinnaḥ asi chinnaḥ dadhinā
translated: fed by the king, killed by the king, cut by a sword, cut by a sword, like a father, like a father, curds added to

original: bhojanaṃ dadhibhojanaṃ, guḷena misso odano guḷodano-iha pana vutti padenevopasittādi
analyzed: bhojanam dadhi bhojanam guḷena missaḥ odanaḥ guḷa odanaḥ iha pana vutti padena iva upasitta ādi
translated: food, food with curds, rice mixed with sugar, sugar-rice. But here, by the word itself, added with curds, etc.,

original: kriyāyākhyāpanato na tatthāyuttatthatā-kvacivuttiyeva-urago-kvaci vākyameva-erasunā
analyzed: na vākyam eva erasunā
translated: because the action is expressed, it is not appropriate there. In some places, only the word - snake. In some places, only the sentence - cut by a plough.

original: chinnavā, dassanena pahātabbā, brāhmaṇassa deyyaṃbrāhmaṇadeyyaṃyupāya dāru yupadāru,
analyzed: dassanena pahātabbā brāhmaṇassa deyyam brāhmaṇa deyyam yupāya dāru yupa dāru
translated: to be abandoned by seeing, to be given to a brahmin, wood with a hole, wood with a hole,

original: idha nahoti saṅghassa dātabbaṃ-gāmā niggato gāma niggato, kvacivutti yeva-kammajaṃ-idha
analyzed: idha saṅghassa dātabbaṃgāmā niggataḥ gāma niggataḥ
translated: here it is not appropriate - to be given to the Sangha. Gone out from the village, gone out from the village. In some places, only the word - born of kamma. Here

original: na hoti rukkhā patito-rañño puriso rājapuriso-bahulādhikārā ntamānaniddhāriyapuraṇa
analyzed: na hoti puriso
translated: it is not appropriate - fallen from the tree. The king's man, the king's man. Having many duties, the final case ending is dropped.

original: bhāvati bhāvati ttatthehi nahoti-mamānukubbaṃ, mamānukurukamāno, gunnaṃkaṇhā sampannakhīratamā,
analyzed: bhāvati bhāvati sampanna khīratamā
translated: the state of being, the state of being. By these, it is not appropriate here - following me, desiring to imitate me, the black of the cows, the best of the completed milk,

original: sissānaṃ pañcamo, paṭassa sukkatā-kvaci hoteva-vattamānasāmīpyaṃ, phalānaṃ titto,
analyzed: sissānam pañcamaḥ paṭassa hotā iva vatta māna sāmīpyam phalānam tittaḥ
translated: the fifth of the disciples, the whiteness of the cloth. In some places, it is appropriate - the proximity of the present, the sourness of the fruits,

original: phalānaṃ suhito, brāhmaṇassa kaṇhā dantā iccatra dantāpekkhā chaṭṭhiti kaṇhenasambandhābhāvā
analyzed: brāhmaṇassa kaṇhāḥ dantāḥ iccatra danta apekkhā chaṭṭh iti
translated: “The fruit of the brahmin’s black teeth” : here the teeth are expected, and because of the absence of a relation with the black,

original: na samāso-aññamaññasambandhānaṃhi samāsoyadā tu kaṇhā ca te dantā ceti visesanasmāso
analyzed: na samāsaḥ aññamañña sambandhānam hi samāsaḥ yadā tu kaṇhā ca te dantā ca iti
translated: the compound is not made. For a compound is made when there is a relation of mutual dependence. But when they are black and teeth, then the compound is made by the sixth case as a determinative compound.

original: tadā chaṭṭhi kaṇhadantāpekkāti brāhmaṇakaṇhadantāti hoteva-rañño māgadhassa dhanamiccatra
analyzed: tadā kaṇha danta apekkā ati brāhmaṇa kaṇha dantā ati hotevaraññaḥ māgadhassa
translated: Then the sixth case is expected in relation to the black teeth. So it is made: “The brahmin’s black teeth.” “The wealth of the Magadhan king” : here

original: raññoti chaṭṭhi dhanamapekkhate na māgadhaṃ rājā eva māgadhasadadena vuccateti bhedābhāvā🔽sambandhābhāvoti tulyādhikaraṇena māgadhena saha rājā na samasyate-rañño asso ca
analyzed: rañño ti dhanam apekkhate na māgadham rājā eva māgadha sadadena vuccate iti bheda abhāvā  tulya adhikaraṇena māgadhena saha rājā na samasyate iraññaḥ ca
translated: the sixth case is expected in relation to the wealth, not to the Magadhan. The king is called “the Magadhan” because he has the Magadhan land. So there is no difference.

original: puriso cāti ettha rañño asso purisoti ca paccekaṃ sambandhato sāpekkatāya na samāso-asso
analyzed: puriso ca ati ettha raññaḥ asso puriso ti ca paccekam sambandhato sa apekka tāya na samāsaḥ asso
translated: Because there is no relation, the king is not compounded with the Magadhan, which has the same base. “The king’s horse and man” : here the king’s horse and the king’s man are not compounded because of the relation of dependence on the individual.

original: ca puriso cāti catthasamāse kate tu rājassapurisāti hotevaññānapekkhattā-rañño garuputtoti
analyzed: ca puriso ca ati cattha samāse kate tu garu putto ti
translated: “The horse and the man” : but when the compound is made as a sixth case determinative compound, it becomes “the king’s horse and man,” because of the expectation of the genitive. “The king’s heavy son” :

original: ettha pana rājāpekkhinopi garuno puttena saha samāso gamakattā-gamakattampihi samāsassa
analyzed: ettha pana rāja apekkhino api garuno puttena saha samāsaḥ samāsassa
translated: Herein, even though the king is not expected, the compound is a dvanda because of the conjunction “and” (ca).

original: nibandhanaṃ-dāne soṇḍo dānasoṇḍo-kvaci vuttiyeva-pabbataṭṭho-kvacī samāsepi vibhatyalopo-jane suto.
analyzed: nibandhanam dāne soṇḍaḥ dāna soṇḍaḥ kvaci samāse pi sutaḥ
translated: The reason for the compound is the giving of the gift, the greedy giver of gifts. Sometimes there is only the usage. The meaning of mountain. Sometimes even in a compound there is elision of the case ending. It is heard by the people.

original: Visesanamekatthena.
analyzed: visesanam ekatthena
translated: The distinction is with the same meaning as the distinguished.

original: Visesanaṃ syādyantaṃ vasessena syādyantena samānādhikāraṇena sahekatthaṃ hoti-nīlañca
analyzed: visesanam syādi antam syādi antena samāna adhikāraṇena saha ikattham
translated: The distinguished, ending in a suffix, is with the same meaning as that which ends in a suffix, with which it has the same case relation. Blue

original: taṃ uppalaṃ ceti niluppalaṃ-vākye tulyādhikaraṇabhāvappakāsanatthaṃ catasaddappayogo-vuttiyantu
analyzed: tam uppalam ca iti tulya adhikaraṇa bhāva ppakāsana ttham
translated: and that lotus is the blue lotus. In a sentence, the use of the word “and” is for the purpose of showing the same case relation. But in the usage,

original: samāseneva tappakāsanato na tappayogo-eva maññatrāpi vuttaṭṭhānamappayogo-bahulādhikārā
analyzed: samāsena iva tad pakāsanataḥ na tad payogaḥ eva maññatra api vutta ṭṭhānam appayogaḥ bahula adhikārā
translated: because it is shown by the compound itself, there is no use of “and”. In the same way, in the case of “thinking”, there is no use of the word “and”. Because of the frequent use of “and”,

original: kvaci upamānabhutaṃ visesanamparaṃ bhavati-sīho’ca sīho-muni ca so sīho cāti munisīho-munisaddoyeva
analyzed: kvaci upamāna bhutam visesanam param bhavati sīho ca sīho muni ca saḥ sīho ca ati muni sīho muni saddaḥ yā iva
translated: sometimes the distinguished, which is the object of comparison, is the other. The lion and he is a lion, and he is a sage, therefore he is a sage-lion. The word “sage”🔽is itself the distinguished. Because it is so, when “lion” is said, in the common characteristic of the lion whether figurative or not, the word “sage”

original: vā visesanaṃ-tathāhi-sīhoti vutte upacaritānupacaritasīhānaṃ sāmaññappatītiyaṃ munisaddo
analyzed: vā visesanam tathā hi sīhaḥ ti vutte upacarita anupacarita sīhānam sāmañña ppatītiyam muni saddaḥ
translated: is the distinguished.

original: viseseti-sīlameva dhanaṃ sīladhanaṃ-dhammoti sammato dhammasammato-mahanti ca sā
analyzed: visesa iti sīlam eva dhanam sīla dhanam dhammaḥ ti sammataḥ dhamma sammataḥ mahanti ca sā
translated: The wealth of virtue is the virtue itself which is the wealth. The one approved by Dhamma is the one approved by the Dhamma. The great faith is the great confidence.

original: saddhā cāti samāse kate-“itthiyambhāsitapumitthi pumevekattha”ta pumbhāvā ṅīppaccayābhāvo-“ṭantantunanti”ntassa
analyzed: saddhā ca ati samāse kate itthiyam bhāsita pum itthi pum eve katthata pum bhāvāḥ ṅīp paccaya ābhāvaḥ ṭanta ntu nanti ntassa
translated: When the compound is made, “itthiyambhāsitapumitthi pumevekattha” (Pā. 1.1.58), the feminine form is used for the masculine. The absence of the feminine ending is due to the absence of the condition.🔽The “t” is lengthened by the rule “ṭantantunanti” (Pā. 1.2.1).

original: ṭe-“byañjane dīgharassā”ti dighe-mahāsaddhā.
analyzed: ṭe bi añjane dīgha raḥ sāti dighe mahā saddhā
translated: The “t” is lengthened by the rule “byañjane dīgharassā” (Pā. 1.2.2). The great faith.

original: Naña.
analyzed: nañaḥ
translated: The negative particle.

original: Nañiccetaṃ syādyantaṃ syādyantena sahekatthaṃ hoti-ñakāro“ṭanaññassā”ti visesanattho-pāmanaputtādīsu mā hotūti.
analyzed: nañ it ca itam syādi antam syādi antena saha ikattham visesa nattha upāmana putta ādīsu mā hotu uti
translated: The negative particle is used at the end of a word and has the same meaning as when used at the end of a sentence. The “ñ” is for the purpose of distinguishing. Let it not be so in the case of “pāmanaputtā” and so on.

original: Ṭanaññassa.
analyzed: ṭa nañ ñassa
translated: The negative particle.

original: Uttarapade nañsaddassa ṭa hoti-na brāhmaṇo abrāhmaṇo, nañayaṃ pariyudāsavutti pasajjappaṭisedhavutti
analyzed: uttara pade nañ saddassa ṭa hoti na brāhmaṇaḥ a brāhmaṇaḥ pariyudāsa vutti pasajja ppaṭisedha vutti
translated: The “ñ” becomes “ṭ” in the following word. “Not a brahmin” is “anabrāhmaṇa.” The negative particle has the meaning of exclusion, of prohibition,🔽and of contrast.

original: ca-paṭhamapakkhe-brāhmaṇa añño brāhmaṇantānajjhāsino khattiyādi brāhmaṇa sadisoyeva
analyzed: ca paṭhama pakkhe brāhmaṇa aññaḥ khattiya ādi brāhmaṇa sadisaḥ yeva
translated: In the first case, “a brahmin other than a brahmin” means a khattiya, etc., who is like a brahmin.

original: abrāhmaṇeti vutte patiyate-itarasmiṃ pana pakkhe kenaci saṃsayanimittena khattiyādo
analyzed: a brāhmaṇa iti vutte patiyate itarasmin pana pakkhe kenaci saṃsaya nimittena khattiya ādaḥ
translated: When it is said “not a brahmin,” it is understood. But in the other case, due to some cause of doubt, a khattiya, etc.,

original: brāhmaṇeti pavantassa micchāñāṇanivutti karīyati-brāhmaṇe yaṃ’na bhavati brāhmaṇeti
analyzed: brāhmaṇa iti bhavati brāhmaṇa iti
translated: The statement “to one who is called a brahmin, the expression ‘brahmin’ is not made” is made in order to show the non-existence of wrong knowledge in a brahmin.

original: brāhmaṇantajjhāsito na bhavatīti attho-tattha vinā sadisattaṃ micchāñāṇasambhavā
analyzed: na bhavati iti vinā micchā ñāṇa sambhavā
translated: The meaning is: “he does not become one who is desirous of being a brahmin.” There, because of the possibility of wrong knowledge without similarity,

original: payogasāmatthiyā ca sadisapaṭippatti taggatāca liṅgasaṅkhyā bhavanti-atoyevoccate
analyzed: payoga sāmatthiyā ca taggatā ca liṅga saṅkhyāḥ bhavanti atas yā iva uccate
translated: and because of the capability of the expression, and because of the state of being in the same case of the expression of similarity, the gender and number are made.🔽Therefore, it is said:

original: nañivayutta maññasadisādhikaraṇe tathā hi atthasampaccayoti-tadevaṃ pakkhañcayeva
analyzed: nañ iva yutta mañ ña sadisa adhikaraṇe tathā hi
translated: “In the case of nañ with mañ and asadis, the meaning is as follows: thus, because of the meaning,🔽in this way, the former word is predominant.

original: pubbapadatthappadhānattaṃ-evamanasso-ihatu.
analyzed: pubba pada attha ppadhāna ttam eva manassaḥ ihatu
translated: Thus, in this way, in this case.

original: Ana sare.
analyzed: ana sare
translated: Ana after sarā.

original: Sarādo uttarapade nañsaddassa ana hotīti nassa ana.
analyzed: sara ādaḥ uttara pade nañ saddassa ana hoti iti nassa ana
translated: Ana is for nañ after sarā in the following word.

original: Kupādayo niccamasyādividhimhi.
analyzed: kupa ādayaḥ
translated: Kupādayo niccamasyādividhimhi.🔽The words kus and pādayo are always in the same meaning with the suffix syādyanta. They are in the domain of the rule of syādividhi, except in other cases.

original: Kusaddo pādayo ca syādyantena sahekatthā honti niccaṃ syādividhivisayato’ññattha-kucchito
analyzed: ku saddaḥ pādayaḥ ca syādi antena saha ikatthāḥ honti niccam
translated: Kucchito

original: brāhmaṇo kubrāhmaṇo-evaṃkupuriso-“purise vā”ti pakkhe kādese-kāpuriso-īsakaṃ uṇhaṃ
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ vā ati pakkhe uṇhaṃ
translated: brahmano kubrāhmaṇo. Thus, kupuriso. “In the case of puriso,” in the alternative, kādese. Kāpuriso. Īsakam uṇhaṃ

original: kaduṇhaṃ-“sare kada kussuttaratthe”ti kussa kadādeso-appakaṃ lavaṇaṃ kālavaṇaṃ-“kāppatthe”ti kādeso.
analyzed: kad uṇha sare kada kussu ttara tthe iti kussa kad ādesaḥ appakam lavaṇam kālavaṇam kāppa tthe iti ka ādesaḥ
translated: Kaduṇhaṃ is “a little salt” (kaduṇaṃ); the k is the k of kadā.

original: Pādayo gatādyatthe paṭhamāya.
analyzed: pādayaḥ gata ādi a tthe paṭhamāya
translated: Pādayo gatādyatthe paṭhamāya.

original: Pagato ācariyo pācariyo-evaṃ pantevāsī-suṭṭhukataṃ sukataṃ-kicchena kataṃ dukkataṃ.
analyzed: pagataḥ ācariyaḥ pācariyaḥ evam pantevāsī suṭṭhukatam su kataṃkicchena katam dukkatam
translated: Pagato ācariyo pācariyo; thus pantevāsī; suṭṭhukataṃ sukataṃ; kicchena kataṃ dukkataṃ.

original: Accādayo kantādyatthe dutiyāya.
analyzed: ac ca ādayaḥ kanta ādi atthe dutiyāya
translated: Accādayo kantādyatthe dutiyāya.

original: Atikkanto mālamatimālo.
analyzed: atikkantaḥ mālam atimālaḥ
translated: Atikkanto mālamatimālo.

original: Ghapassāntasyāppakānassa.
analyzed: gha passa antasya ap pa kānassa
translated: Ghapassāntasyāppakānassa.

original: Antabhutassāppadhānassa ghapassa syādisu rasso hotīti rasso.
analyzed: anta bhutassa a p padhānassa ghapassa syāt isu rassaḥ hoti iti rassaḥ
translated: Antabhutassāppadhānassa ghapassa syādisu rasso hotīti rasso.

original: Avavādayo kuṭṭhādyatthe tatiyāya.
analyzed: avavādayo kuṭṭha ādi atthe tatiyāya
translated: Avavādayo kuṭṭhādyatthe tatiyāya.

original: Avakuṭṭhaṃ kokilāya vanamavakokilaṃ-avakuṭṭhanti pariccattaṃ.
analyzed: avakuṭṭham kokilāya vanam avakokilam avakuṭṭhanti pariccattam
translated: Avakuṭṭhaṃ kokilāya vanamavakokilaṃ; avakuṭṭhanti pariccattaṃ.

original: Pariyādayo gilānādyatthe catutthiyā.
analyzed: pariya ādayaḥ gilāna ādi atthe catutthiyā
translated: Pariyādayo gilānādyatthe catutthiyā.

original: Parigilāno’jjhenāya pariyajjheno.
analyzed: parigilāna ujjhenāya
translated: Parigilāno’jjhenāya pariyajjheno.

original: Nyādayo kantādyatthe pañcamiyā.
analyzed: ni ādayo kanta ādi atthe pañcamyā
translated: Nyādayo kantādyatthe pañcamiyā.

original: Nikkanto kosambiyā nikkosambi-ghapādinā rasso.
analyzed: nikkantaḥ kosambiyā nikkosambigha pādinā rassaḥ
translated: Nikkanto kosambiyā nikkosambi; ghapādinā rasso.

original: Vā nekaññatthe.
analyzed: vā na ikaññatthe
translated: Vā nekaññatthe.

original: Anekaṃ syādyanta maññassa padassatthe ekatthaṃ vā hoti-o tiṇṇo haṃso yaṃ so otiṇṇahaṃso-(jalāsayo).
analyzed: anekam syāt yanta maññassa padassa atthe ekattham vā tiṇṇaḥ haṃsaḥ yam saḥ
translated: In the case of the word maññassa, the locative is made singular, or else it is made the same as the base, thus: Otiṇṇahaṃso, yaṃ so otiṇṇahaṃso (the swan that has descended).

original: Jito māro yena so jitamāro-(bhagavā)-jinnotaru yena so chinnataru(pharasu)dinno suṅko
analyzed: jitaḥ māraḥ yena saḥ yena saḥ
translated: Jitamāro, yena so jitamāro (the Blessed One). Chinnataru, yena so chinnataru (the axe). Dinnasuṅko,

original: yassaso dinnasuṅko(rājā)-apagataṃ kālakaṃ yasmā so apagatakālako (paṭo)pahutaṃ dhanaṃ
analyzed: dinnasuṅko rājā apagatam kālakam so apagata kālakaḥ paṭa upahutam dhanam
translated: yassaso dinnasuṅko (the king). Apagatakālako, yasmā so apagatakālako (the cloth). Pahutadhano,

original: yassa so pahutadhano-(puriso)-natthi samo yassa so asamo-nassa ṭādeso-cittā gāvo
analyzed: yassa saḥ samaḥ yassa saḥ a sama ūnassa ṭā desa ucittāḥ gāvaḥ
translated: yassaso pahutadhano (the man). Asamo, yassa so asamo (the unequalled one). Ṭādeso, cittā gāvo,

original: yassāti samāse kate.
analyzed: yaḥ sā ati samāse kate
translated: yassāti samāse kate.

original: Gossu
analyzed: gossu
translated: Gossu

original: Antabhutassāppadhānassa gossa syādīsu u hoti-cittagu-(gomā)-mattāneke gajā yasmiṃ
analyzed: anta bhutassa appadhānassa gossa gajāḥ yasmin
translated: In the case of the word gossa, the locative is made singular in the case of the base ending in a vowel, thus: Cittagu (the cow-pen). Mattāneke gajā yasmiṃ,

original: taṃ mattānekagajaṃ-(vanaṃ) saha puttena vattamāno saputto saha putto vā-“sahassa
analyzed: tam matta anekagajaṃvanam saha puttena vattamānaḥ sa puttaḥ saha puttaḥ vāsahassa
translated: taṃ mattānekagajaṃ (the forest). Saha puttena vattamāno, saputto, saha putto vā. “Sahassa

original: so’ññatthe“ti pakkhe sahassa so-dhavā ca badirā ca palāsā ceti viggahe.🔽Catthe.
analyzed: soññatthā iti pakkhe sahassa sodhavā ca badirā ca palāsā ca iti viggahe 🔽catthe
translated: so’ññatthe” ti pakkhe, sahassa so. Dhavo ca badirā ca palāsā ceti viggahe.

original: Anekaṃ syādyantaṃ catthe ekatthaṃ vā bhavati-samuccayo’nvāvayo itarītarayogo samāhāro
analyzed: anekam syādi antam catthe ekattham vā itarītara yogo samāhāraḥ
translated: The meaning of a compound is one or many.🔽The meaning of a compound is of four kinds: a collection, a separation, a conjunction, and a combination.

original: ceti catatāro catthā-tattha itarītarayoge samāhāre ca ekatthībhāvo sambhavati padānaṃ
analyzed: ca iti catatāraḥ itarītara yoge samāhāre ca ekatthībhāvaḥ sambhavati padānam
translated: In the case of a conjunction and a combination, the meaning of the words is one.

original: aññamaññasambandhato-na samuccaye nāpyanvācaye tadabhāvato, casaddanivutti.
analyzed: samuccaye na api anvācaye tad abhāvataḥ
translated: Because of the connection of the words with each other, not in a collection or a separation, because of the absence of that. The word “ca” is a statement.

original: Samāhāre napuṃsakaṃ.
analyzed: samāhāre napuṃsakam
translated: In a combination, the gender is neuter.

original: Catthe samāhāre yadekatthaṃ taṃ napuṃsakaliṅgaṃ bhavati-samāhārassekattā ekavacanameva-dhavakhadirapalāsaṃ-kattha
analyzed: catthe samāhāre yat ekattham tam napuṃsaka liṅgam bhavati samāhāraḥ ekattā ekavacanam eva dhava khadira palā saṃkattha
translated: In a compound of the combination type, the gender is neuter, because of the unity of the collection. The number is singular only. “Dhava, khadira, palāsa.”

original: ci na hoti’sabhāparisāyā’ti ñāpakā-ādhipaccaparivāro-itarītarayoge avayavappadhānattā
analyzed: ci na hoti sabhā parisāya ati avayava ppadhāna ttā
translated: Sometimes it is not so. “Sabhā parisā.” The reason is: “The surrounding of a lord.”🔽In a conjunction, the number is plural, because of the predominance of the parts. “Dhava, khadira, palāsa.”

original: bahuvacanaṃ-dhavakhadirapalāsā-samāse yaṃ pubbaṃ vūttaṃ tadeva pubbaṃ nipatati-kamātikkame
analyzed: bahuvacanaṃ dhava khadira palāsā samāse yam pubbam vūttam tat eva pubbam
translated: In a compound, what was said first comes first. “Kamātikkama.”

original: payojanābhāvā-kvaci vipallāsopi hoti bahulādhikārato-dantānaṃ rājā rājadanto-pāpā
analyzed: rājā
translated: Because of the absence of a purpose. Sometimes there is also a reversal, because of the predominance of the many. “Rājā dantānaṃ, rājadanto.” “Pāpā

original: bhumi yasmiṃ pāpā ca sābhumi ceti vā viggayha samāse samāsantveccādhikāro.🔽Pāpādīhi bhumiyā.
analyzed: bhumi yasmin ca ca iti vā samāse  pāpa ādīhi bhumiyā
translated: In the compound pāpabhumī, the word bhumī is a locative in the sense of ‘place’.🔽With pāpa, etc., the locative case

original: Pāpādīhi parā yā bhumi tassā samāsanto a hoti-pāpabhumaṃ, (ṭhānaṃ)-itthiyamiccādināāppaccayo nivattane-jātiyā upa lakkhitā bhumi jātibhumaṃ.
analyzed: pāpa ādīhi parā yā bhumi tassā samāsa antaḥ hoti pāpa bhumam ṭhānam itthiyam iccādinā āp paccayaḥ nivattane jātiyā upa lakkhitā bhumi jāti bhumam
translated: After pāpa, etc., the locative case has the affix a in the compound: pāpabhumī, (place) of evil; itthibhumī, (place) of women; etc. The affix ā is not used in the negative: ajātibhūmi, (place) not of birth.

original: Saṅkhyāhi
analyzed: saṅkhyāhi
translated: With numerals

original: Saṅkhyāhi parā yā bhumi tassā samāsanto ahoti-dve bhumiyo assāti dvībhumaṃ-evaṃ tibhumaṃ, catubhumaṃ-bahulādhikārā kvaci na hekāti-catubhumi.🔽Dīghāhovassekadesehi ca ratyā.🔽Dīghādīhi asaṅkhyehi saṅkhyāhi ca parasmā rattisaddā anaññāsaṅkhyatthesu samasitā🔽samāsanto a hoti-dīghā ca sā ratti cāti dīgharattaṃ-aho ca ratti ca ahorattaṃ-ahassa
analyzed: parā yā bhumi tassā assa ati dvībhumam evam ti bhumam catu bhumam bahula adhikārā kvaci na hekā ati catu bhumi  dīgha aha u vassa ika desehi ca ratyā  dīgha ādīhi asaṅkhyehi saṅkhyāhi ca parasmā ratti saddāḥ anañña asaṅkhya tthesu samasitā  samāsantaḥ a hotidīghā ca sā ratti ca ati dīgha rattaṃahaḥ ca ratti ca ahorattaṃahassa
translated: After numerals, the locative case has the affix a in the compound: dvībhumī, (place) of two; tibhumī, (place) of three; catubhumī, (place) of four; catubhūmi, (place) of four; bahubhūmi, (place) of many.🔽And with dīgha, etc., and ratti, with the meaning of ‘night’.

original: apādittā “manādyapādīnamo maye cā”ti o-vassāsu ratti vassārattaṃ-pubbā ca sā ratti
analyzed: maye ca ati ovassāsu ratti ca sā ratti
translated: With dīgha, etc., and with numerals, the locative case is compounded with ratti, with the meaning of ‘night’, and the affix a is added: dīgha and ratti are dīgharattaṃ, (long night); aho and ratti are ahorattaṃ, (day and night); the affix o is added to a by the rule manādyapādīnamo maye ca; vassāsu ratti is vassārattaṃ, (rainy night); pubba and ratti are pubbārattaṃ, (early night).

original: cātī pubbarattaṃ-evaṃ apararattaṃ, aḍḍharattaṃ-atikkanto rattiṃ atiratto-dvinnaṃ
analyzed: cātī pubba rattam evam apara rattam aḍḍha rattam atikkantaḥ rattim ati ratta udvinnam
translated: cātī pubbarattaṃ-evaṃ apararattaṃ, aḍḍharattaṃ-atikkanto rattiṃ atiratto-dvinnaṃ

original: rattīnaṃ samāhāro dvirattaṃ-anaññāsaṅkhyatthesutveva-digharatti-(hemanto)-upa ratti-kvaci
analyzed: rattīnam samāhāraḥ dvi rattam an aññā saṅkhyā tthesu tu eva digha ratti hemantaḥ upa ratti kvaci
translated: rattīnaṃ samāhāro dvirattaṃ-anaññāsaṅkhyatthesutveva-digharatti-(hemanto)-upa ratti-kvaci

original: hoteva bahulaṃ vidhānā-yathārattaṃ.
analyzed: hotā iva bahulam vidhāna a yathārattam
translated: hoteva bahulaṃ vidhānā-yathārattaṃ.

original: Gotva catthe cālope.
analyzed: go tva ca tthe ca ā lope
translated: Gotva catthe cālope.

original: Gosaddā alopacisayā samāsanto a hoti na ce catthe
analyzed: go saddāḥ a lopa ci sayā samāsa antaḥ a hoti na ce ca tthe
translated: Gosaddā alopacisayā samāsanto a hoti na ce catthe

original: Samāso aññapadatthe asaṅkhyatte ca-rañño go rājagavo-avaṅa-pañca gāvo dhanamassa
analyzed: samāsaḥ añña padatthe asaṅkhyatte caraññaḥ goḥ gāvaḥ dhanam assa
translated: Samāso aññapadatthe asaṅkhyatte ca-rañño go rājagavo-avaṅa-pañca gāvo dhanamassa

original: pañcagavadhano-visesanasamāsagabbho aññapadatthasamāso-dasannaṃ gunnaṃ samāhārodasagavaṃ-alopeti
analyzed: pañcagava dhanaḥ visesana samāsagabbhaḥ añña padattha samāsa udasannam gunnam samāhāra udasagava a lopa iti
translated: pañcagavadhano-visesanasamāsagabbho aññapadatthasamāso-dasannaṃ gunnaṃ samāhārodasagavaṃ-alopeti

original: kiṃ?-Pañcahigobhi kīto pañcagu-visesanasamāse-“tena kataṃ kīta”miccādinā ṇike “lopo”ti
analyzed: kim pañca hi gobhi kītaḥ pañcagu visesana samāsa etena katam kītam iccādinā ṇike lopaḥ iti
translated: kiṃ?-Pañcahigobhi kīto pañcagu-visesanasamāse-“tena kataṃ kīta”miccādinā ṇike “lopo”ti

original: tassa lope ca kane “gossuti ukāro-avattheti kiṃ?-Ajassagāvo-anaññāsaṅkhyattheyutveva-cittagu,
analyzed: tassa lope ca kane goḥ su ti ukāraḥ avatthā iti kim ajassa gāvaḥ anaññā saṅkhyattheyu tu eva cittagu
translated: tassa lope ca kane “gossuti ukāro-avattheti kiṃ?-Ajassagāvo-anaññāsaṅkhyattheyutveva-cittagu,

original: upagu-visālāni akkhīni assāti aññapadatthasamāse“akkhismāññatthe”ti akāre-visālakkho-padhānatthatāvasena
analyzed: upagu visālāni akkhīni assa ati añña padattha samāse akkhi sma aññattha iti akāre visāla kkha upadhāna attha tā vasena
translated: The eyes of Upagu are large, is a compound with a different meaning in the second term. “The akkara is in the sense of ‘eyes’ and ‘another’ ” (Pā. 1.4.10).

original: catubbidhamekattaṃ tividhanti keci-vuttahi.
analyzed: catubbidham ekattam tividhanti
translated: Some say that the unity is fourfold and threefold by the sense of “akkhī” and “visāla”.

original: Pubbuttarobhayaññatthamiccekatthaṃ catubbidhaṃ visessaññobhayatthatā tidhā vakkhanti taṃ pare.
analyzed: catubbidham tam pare
translated: The unity is fourfold by the sense of “pubbu” and “uttara” and “ubhaya” and “añña”. The others will say that it is threefold by the sense of “visesa” and “añña” and “ubhaya”.

original: Ekatthaṃ.
analyzed: ekattham
translated: Unity.

original: Atha itthippaccayantā niddisīyante.
analyzed: atha itthippaccayantāḥ niddisīyante
translated: Now the feminine endings are demonstrated.

original: Itthiyamatvā.
analyzed: itthiyam atvā
translated: Feminine.

original: Itthiyaṃ vattamānato akārantato nāmasmā āppaccayo hoti-devadattā, ajā, kokilā, iccādi.
analyzed: itthiyam vattamānataḥ akāra antataḥ nāmasmai āp paccayaḥ hoti devadattā ajā kokilā iccādi
translated: The ā-ending is the feminine ending from a noun ending in a vowel. devadattā, ajā, kokilā, etc.

original: Nadādito ṅī.🔽Ākatigaṇe’yaṃ-nadādīhi itthiyaṃ ṅīppaccayo hoti ṅakāro “ntantunaṃ ṅimhi to ve”ti
analyzed: nada āditaḥ ṅī  ā kati gaṇa iyam nad ādīhi itthiyam ṅīp paccayaḥ hoti ṅakāraḥ n ta n tunam ṅ imhi taḥ vā iti
translated: From nadā, etc., ṅī.🔽This is in the ā-declension. “From nadā, etc., the feminine ending is ṅī” (Pā. 1.1.65).

original: saṅketattho-nadī, mahī, kumārī, taruṇi, vāruṇi, gotamī, gacchanti-“ntantunaṃ ṅimhi
analyzed: mahī kumārī taruṇi vāruṇi gotamī ṅimhi
translated: The meaning of saṅketa is “river”. nadī, mahī, kumārī, taruṇi, vāruṇi, gotamī, gacchanti. “From ntan and tuna, ṅī is changed to ṅimhi to” (Pā. 1.1.66).

original: to ve”ti vā takāre-gacchatī-gacchatī-evaṃ guṇavanti, guṇavatī-“gotovā“ti nadādisu
analyzed: taḥ vā iti vā takāre gacchatī gacchatī evam guṇavanti nada ādisu
translated: The meaning of takka is “she goes”. gacchatī. gacchatī. “From ntan and tuna, ṅī is changed to ṅimhi to” (Pā. 1.1.66).🔽“From ntan and tuna, ṅī is changed to ṅimhi to” (Pā. 1.1.66).

original: pāṭhā vā ṅīmhi “gossāvaṅa”ti gosaddassa āvaṅa-gāvī, go.
analyzed: pāṭhā vā ṅīmhi gossa āvaṅati go saddassa āvaṅagāvī go
translated: Or in ṅī: “gossāvaṅa” means a cow’s calf, a young cow.

original: Yakkhāditvinī ca.
analyzed: yak kha āditvinī ca
translated: And a female spirit, etc.

original: Yakkhādito itthīyaminī hoti ṅī ca-yakkhinī,yakkhī-nāginī,nāgī.
analyzed: yakkha āditaḥ itthī yaminī hoti ṅī ca yakkhinī yakkhī nāginī nāgī
translated: A female spirit, etc., has the feminine ending ṅī: yakkhinī, nāginī, nāgī.

original: Yuvaṇṇehi nī.
analyzed: yuvaṇṇehi nī
translated: In young women, ṇī.

original: Itthiyamivaṇṇuvaṇṇantehi nī hoti bahulaṃ-payatapāṇinī, daṇḍinī, bhikkhunī, paracittavidunī.
analyzed: nī hoti bahulaṃ payata pāṇinī daṇḍinī bhikkhunī para citta vidunī
translated: In young women, in the sense of “having a complexion like a woman’s,” ṇī is often used: payatapāṇinī, daṇḍinī, bhikkhunī, paracittavidunī.

original: Yuvā tī.
analyzed: yuvā tī
translated: In young men, tī.

original: Yuvasaddato tī hotitthiyaṃ-yuvatī.
analyzed: tī hotitthiyaṃyuvatī
translated: In young men, in the sense of “having a complexion like a young man’s,” tī is used: yuvatī.

original: Itthippaccayantā.
analyzed: itthip paccayantā
translated: In the sense of “having a woman as a condition.”

original: Atha ṇadayo vuccante-raghussāpaccamīti viggahe.
analyzed: atha ṇa dayaḥ vuccante ira ghussā paccamī iti viggahe
translated: Now ṇ, etc., are stated: raghussāpaccamīti viggahe.

original: Ṇe vāpacce.
analyzed: ṇe vā a pacce
translated: Or in apacce.

original: Chaṭṭhiyantā nāmasmā vā ṇappaccayo hotapacce’bhidheyye-ṇakāro ṇanubandhakāriyattho-ṇeneva apaccatthassa vuttattā apaccasaddāppayogo-“ekatthatāya”miti syādi lopo.
analyzed: vā ṇap paccayaḥ hota pacca ibhidheyye ṇakāraḥ a pacca ibhidheyye ṇakāraḥ a pacca tthassa vutta ttā a pacca sadda appayoga ekattha tā ayam iti syādi lopaḥ
translated: After a noun in the sixth case, the affix ṇ is added in the sense of “in apacca”: ṇ is a suffix in the sense of “doing.” Since the meaning of “in apacca” is stated by ṇ itself, the word apacca is not used. “Because of the single meaning,” the i is elided.

original: Sarānamādissāyuvaṇṇassā e o ṇanubandhe.
analyzed: sara anam ādi ssā yu vaṇ ṇassā e o ṇ anubandhe
translated: In sarānamādissāyuvaṇṇassā e o ṇanubandhe.

original: Sarānamādibhuta ye akārivaṇṇavaṇṇā tesaṃ ā e o honti yathākkamaṃ ṇanubandheti akārassa akāro.
analyzed: ye akāri vaṇṇa vaṇṇā tesam ā e o honti yathākkamam akārassa akāraḥ
translated: The vowels a, e, and o are the respective vowels of the words sarānamādissā and yuvaṇṇassā. They become ā, e, and o respectively when ṇ is a suffix.

original: Uvaṇṇassāvaṅa sare
analyzed: u vaṇ ṇassa avaṅa sare
translated: In sarānamādissāyuvaṇṇassā e o ṇanubandhe.

original: Sarādo ṇanubandhe uvaṇṇassa avaṅhoti-tato syādi-rāghavoccādi-itthiyaṃ-rāghavaccādi-vā vidhānā raghussāpaccaṃ ragvapaccantipi hoti.
analyzed: sa rādaḥ ṇ anubandhe u vaṇṇassa vidhānā raghussāpaccam hoti
translated: Sarādo ṇanubandhe uvaṇṇassa avaṅhoti-tato syādi-rāghavoccādi-itthiyaṃ-rāghavaccādi-vā vidhānā raghussāpaccaṃ ragvapaccantipi hoti.

original: Ṇadayo’bhidheyyaliṅgā apacce tvanapuṃsakā
analyzed: ṇa t ayaḥ abhidheyya liṅgāḥ a pacce tu a napuṃsakā
translated: Ṇadayo’bhidheyyaliṅgā apacce tvanapuṃsakā

original: Napuṃsake sakatthe ṇyo bhiyyo bhāvasamūhajā;
analyzed: napuṃsake sakatthe ṇyaḥ bhiyyaḥ bhāva samūha jā
translated: Napuṃsake sakatthe ṇyo bhiyyo bhāvasamūhajā;

original: Tā tutthiyamasaṅakkhyāne tvādi cippaccayantakā
analyzed: tā tutthi yama saṅakkhyāne tu ādi cip paccayantakā
translated: Tā tutthiyamasaṅakkhyāne tvādi cippaccayantakā

original: Napuṃsakena liṅgena saddā’dāhu pumene vā
analyzed: napuṃsakena liṅgena vā
translated: Napuṃsake sakatthe ṇyo bhiyyo bhāvasamūhajā;🔽Tā tutthiyamasaṅakkhyāne tvādi cippaccayantakā

original: Niddissatīti ñatabbamavisese panicchite.🔽Vā apacceti vādhikāro.
analyzed: niddissati iti ñatabbam a visese pa nicchite  vā a pacceti vā adhikāraḥ
translated: Napuṃsake sakatthe ṇyo bhiyyo bhāvasamūhajā;🔽Tā tutthiyamasaṅakkhyāne tvādi cippaccayantakā

original: Vacchādito ṇana ṇayanā.
analyzed: vacchāditaḥ ṇana ṇayanā
translated: Napuṃsake sakatthe ṇyo bhiyyo bhāvasamūhajā;🔽Tā tutthiyamasaṅakkhyāne tvādi cippaccayantakā🔽Napuṃsake sakatthe ṇyo bhiyyo bhāvasamūhajā;🔽Tā tutthiyamasaṅakkhyāne tvādi cippaccayantakā🔽Napuṃsake sakatthe ṇyo bhiyyo bhāvasamūhajā;

original: Vacchādito gottādibhutā gaṇato ca ṇana ṇayanappaccayā honti paputtādo’pacce-paputtappabhuti
analyzed: vacchāditaḥ gotta ādi bhutā gaṇataḥ ca ṇana ṇayana ppaccayāḥ honti
translated: Tā tutthiyamasaṅakkhyāne tvādi cippaccayantakā🔽Napuṃsake sakatthe ṇyo bhiyyo bhāvasamūhajā;🔽Tā tutthiyamasaṅakkhyāne tvādi cippaccayantakā🔽Napuṃsake sakatthe ṇyo bhiyyo bhāvasamūhajā;🔽Tā tutthiyamasaṅakkhyāne tvādi cippaccayantakā

original: gottaṃ-vacchassā paccaṃ vacchāno, vacchāyano-‘saṃyoge kvacī’ti vuttattā na vuddhi-katissāpaccaṃ
analyzed: paccam vacchāno vacchāyano saṃyoge kvaci iti vutta ttā na
translated: Napuṃsake sakatthe ṇyo bhiyyo bhāvasamūhajā;🔽Tā tutthiyamasaṅakkhyāne tvādi cippaccayantakā

original: kaccāno, kaccāyano-yakāracavaggapubba rūpāni-yāgame-kātiyāno.
analyzed: kaccānaḥ kaccāyanaḥ yaka ara ca vagga pubba rūpa aniyāgam ekātiyānaḥ
translated: Napuṃsake sakatthe ṇyo bhiyyo bhāvasamūhajā;

original: Kattikāya apaccamiccevamādi viggahe.
analyzed: kattikāya a paccam iti evamādi viggahe
translated: Tā tutthiyamasaṅakkhyāne

original: Kattikāvidhavādīhi ṇeyyaṇerā.
analyzed: kattikā vidhavā ādīhi ṇeyya ṇerā
translated: The son of a widow of Kattika, of Neyya, of Nera.

original: Kattikādīhi vidhavādīhi ca ṇeyyaṇerā vā yathākkamaṃ, honta pacce-kattikeyyo, veṇateyyo-vedhavero, sāmaṇero.
analyzed: kattikā ādīhi vidhavā ādīhi ca ṇeyya ṇerāḥ vā yathākkamam honta paccekattikeyyaḥ veṇateyyaḥ vedhaveraḥ sāmaṇeraḥ
translated: The son of a widow of Kattika, etc., and of Neyya, of Nera, is respectively Pacce-kattikeyyo, Veṇateyyo, Vedhavero, Sāmaṇero.

original: Ṇya diccādīhi
analyzed: ṇya dit ca ādīhi
translated: Ṇya, dicc, etc.

original: Ditippabhutīhi ṇyo vā gotapacce.
analyzed: diti ppa bhutīhi ṇyaḥ vā go ta pacce
translated: With Diti, etc., Ṇya is the patronymic.

original: Saṃyoge kvaci.
analyzed: saṃyoge kvaci
translated: In some cases in compounds.

original: Sarānamādibhutā ye ayuvaṇṇā tesaṃ ā e o honti kvaci deva saṃyogavisaye ṇanubandheti visayasattamiyā niddiṭṭhattā saṃyogato pubbeva ekāro.
analyzed: ye tesam ā e o honti kvaci saṃyoga visaye visaya sattamiyāḥ niddiṭṭha ttā saṃyogataḥ pubbā eva ekāraḥ
translated: The ā of those who are the first in age and colour becomes e, o, in some cases, in the sphere of compounds with devas, because the sphere is shown in the seventh case.

original: Lopo’vaṇṇivaṇṇānaṃ.
analyzed: lopaḥ vaṇṇi vaṇṇānam
translated: The vowel and consonant of the preceding syllable are elided.

original: Yakārādo paccaye avaṇṇivaṇṇānaṃ lopo hoti-ditiyā apaccaṃ decco, kuṇḍaniyā apaccaṃ koṇḍañño-nassa ñe pubbarūpaṃ-bhātuno apaccaṃ bhātabbo-ettha-
analyzed: yakāra ādaḥ paccaye a vaṇṇi vaṇṇānam lopaḥ hoti ditiyāḥ a paccam deccaḥ kuṇḍaniyāḥ a paccam koṇḍañña ūnassa ñe pubba rūpam bhātunaḥ a paccam
translated: The vowel and consonant of the preceding syllable are elided after the syllable ending in y, Ditiyā apaccaṃ decco, Kuṇḍaniyā apaccaṃ koṇḍañño, Nassa ñe pubbarūpaṃ, Bhātuno apaccaṃ bhātabbo.

original: Yamhi gossa ca.
analyzed: yamhi goḥ ca
translated: In the case of gossa and ca.

original: Yakārādo paccaye gossuvaṇṇassa ca avaṅa hotīti ukārassa avaṅa.
analyzed: yakāra ādaḥ paccaye gossuvaṇṇassa ca avaṅa hoti iti ukārassa avaṅa
translated: The vowel of gossa and the vowel of the preceding syllable are elided after the syllable ending in y, it is said.

original: Ā ṇi.
analyzed: ā ṇi
translated: Ā ṇi.

original: rājā vā pañcālo, māgadho-janapadanāmasmāti kiṃ?-Dāsarathi-khantiyāti kiṃ? Pañcālassabrāhmaṇassāpaccaṃ pañcāli.
analyzed: rājā vā pañcālaḥ māgadhaḥ janapada nāmasma ati kiṃdāsa rathi khantiyā ati kim pañcālassa brāhmaṇassa apaccam pañcāli
translated: Or a king, or Pañcāla, or Magadha, or the name of a country? What? Dāsarathi, or Khantiya? What? Pañcāla, or the country of the brahmin Pañcāla.

original: Ṇya kurusivīhi.
analyzed: ṇya kurusivīhi
translated: Ṇya in Kurusivīha.

original: Kurusivīhapacce raññe ca ṇyo hoti-kurunaṃ apaccaṃ rājāvā korabbo, sebbo.
analyzed: kuru sivi hapacce raññe ca ṇyaḥ hoti kurunam apaccam rājāvā korabbaḥ sebbaḥ
translated: Ṇya is added to Kurusivīha and to a king when they are the object: the country of the Kurus, or King Korabbo, or Sebbo.

original: Ṇa rāgātena rattaṃ.
analyzed: ṇa rattam
translated: Ṇa in ratta from rāga.

original: Rajjate yena so rāgo-tato rāgavācitatiyantato rattamiccetasmiṃ attheṇe hoti-kasāvena
analyzed: rajjate yena saḥ rāgotataḥ rāga vāci tatiyantataḥ rattam icca itasmin attheṇe
translated: Ratta is the name of the colour that is in the mind by the influence of rāga, of which that is the cause: yellow from kasāva,

original: rattaṃ kāsāvaṃ, kosumhaṃ-idha kasmā na hoti’ nīlaṃ pītanti? Guṇavacanattā vināpi
analyzed: rattam kāsāvam kosumhaṃidha kasmā na hoti nīlam pītam ti vinā api
translated: red from rañjana, brown from kasumbha. Why is it not so here in nīla and pīta? Because

original: ṇena ṇatthassābhidhānato.
analyzed: ṇena ṇa tthassa abhidhānataḥ
translated: they are words for a quality, and the meaning of ṇe is expressed without ṇi.

original: Nakkhato ninduyuttena kāle.🔽Tatiyattato nakkhattā tena lakkhite kāle ṇe hoti tañce nakkhattaminduyuttaṃ hoti-phussena
analyzed: nakkhataḥ nindu yuttena kāle  nakkhattā tena lakkhite kāle hoti tat ce nakkhattam indu yuttam
translated: Ṇe in kāla from nakkhatta with the moon.🔽Ṇe is added to kāla when it is defined by nakkhatta and the moon is in that nakkhatta: Phussī, the full moon, is defined by the moon in Phussa.

original: induyuttena lakkhitā puṇṇamāsī phussī, pusso (aho)-maghāya induyuttāyalakkhitā puṇṇamāsī māghī, māgho (aho)
analyzed: indu yuttena lakkhitā puṇṇamāsī phussī pussaḥ ahomaghāya indu yuttāya lakkhitā puṇṇamāsī māghī māghaḥ aho
translated: Māghī, the full moon, is defined by the moon in Maghā.

original: Yā ssa devatā puṇṇamāsi.
analyzed: yā ssa devatā puṇṇamāsi
translated: The deity of the full moon is the name of the month.

original: Seti paṭhamantā asseti chaṭṭhatthe ṇe hoti yaṃ paṭhamantaṃ sā dve devatā puṇṇamāsī🔽vā-sugato devatā asseti sogato-māhindo, yāmo, cāruṇo-phussī pusṇamāsī assa sambandhinīti
analyzed: sā iti paṭhama antā assa iti chaṭṭha atthe hoti yam paṭhama antam sā dve devatā puṇṇamāsī  vāsugataḥ devatāḥ assa iti ca aruṇophussī pusṇamāsī assa sambandhinī iti
translated: The word paṭhamantā is in the sixth case; the word asse is in the locative case; the two deities are the full moon and the new moon.

original: phusso, (māso) evammāgho.
analyzed: phussaḥ māsaḥ evammāghaḥ
translated: The word sogato is in the locative case; the word devatā is in the nominative case; the word asse is in the locative case; the word sambandhinī is in the nominative case; the word phusso is in the nominative case; the word māso is in the nominative case.🔽Thus the chapter on the words beginning with eva is completed.

original: Vyākaraṇamadhite jānāti vātvevamādivaggahe.
analyzed: vyākaraṇam adhite jānāti
translated: One who is skilled in grammar knows this.

original: Tamadhīte tañjānāti kaṇikā ca.
analyzed: tam adhīte tat jānāti kaṇikā ca
translated: Having learned that, one knows this, and also the Kaṇikā.

original: Dutiyantato tamadhīte tañjānātīti etesvattesu ṇehoti koṇiko ca-veyyākaraṇe-katayādesassikārassa“tadā
analyzed: tam adhīte tat jānāti iti etesu attesu koṇikaḥ
translated: Having learned that in the second case, one knows this. In these, the locative case is formed by adding ṇe. Koṇiko is in the grammar. Katayādesassikāra says:

original: desā tadiva bhavanti“ti ñāyā sarānamaccādinā ekāre yāgamadvittāni-ke-kamako, padako-ṇike-suttantiko,
analyzed: tat iva bhavanti ti ñāyā sarā namat ca ādinā e kāre pada koṇike suttantiko
translated: Then, those are in the locative case. By the rule sarānamaccādinā ekāre yāgamadvittāni, the words ke, kamako, padako are in the locative case. ṇike is in the locative case; suttantiko is in the locative case;

original: venayiko-“tena nibbatte”ti tatiyantā nibbattattheṇe-kusambena nibbattā kosambī, (nagarī.)
analyzed: venayikotena nibbattā iti tatiya antā nibbattattha iṇekusambena nibbattā kosambī nagarī
translated: venayiko is in the locative case. Having been born by that is in the third case; the word nibbattā is in the nominative case; the word ṇe is in the locative case; the word kusambena is in the instrumental case; the word nibbattā is in the nominative case; the word kosambī is in the nominative case.

original: Tatra bhave.
analyzed: tatra bhave
translated: There is existence in that.

original: Sattamyantā bhavatthe ṇe hoti-udake bhavo odako-“ajjādīhi tano”ti bhavatthe tano-ajjabhavo ajjatano-evaṃ hīyattano-“ñonamavaṇṇe”ti akāro-“sarambhā dve”ti tassa dvibhāvo.🔽Purātoṇo ca
analyzed: sattamī antāḥ bhavatthe ṇe hoti udake bhavaḥ odakaḥ ajja ādīhi tanoti bhavatthe tano ajja bhavaḥ ajja tano evam hīyat tanoñ ūnam a vaṇṇā iti akāra usarambhāḥ dve iti tassa dvi bhāvaḥ  purā toṇaḥ ca
translated: The suffix ṇe is added to the locative case of the words udaka, ajja, hīna, and saram, and the suffix tano is added to the locative case of the words udaka, ajja, and hīna.

original: Purā iccetasmā bhavatthe ṇe hoti tano va-purā bhavo purāṇe, purātano.🔽Amātvacco.🔽Amā saddato acco hoti bhavatthe-amā bhavo amacco.🔽Majjhāditvimo.
analyzed: purā it ca itasmā bhavatthe ṇe hoti tanaḥ va purā bhavaḥ purāṇe purātano  amātvat caḥ  amā accaḥ hoti bhavattheamā bhavaḥ amacco  majjha ādi tvimaḥ
translated: The suffix ṇe is added to the locative case of the word purā, and the suffix tano is added to it.🔽The suffix acco is added to the locative case of the word amā.

original: Majjhādīhi sattamyantehi bhavatthe imo hoti-majjhe bhavo majjhimo, antimo-kusiṇarāyaṃ bhavo ccevamādiviggahe.🔽Kaṇṇeyya ṇeyyakayyā.
analyzed: majjha ādīhi sattamī antehi bhavatthe imaḥ bhavaḥ majjhimaḥ antimaḥ kusiṇarāyam bhavaḥ cca ivamādi viggahe  kaṇṇeyya ṇeyya kayyā
translated: The suffix imo is added to the locative case of the words majjha, etc.🔽The suffix ṇeyya is added to the locative case of the words kaṇa, kosiṇara, and ṇeyya.

original: Sattamyantā ete paccayā honti bahulaṃ bhavatthe-kaṇa-kosiṇarako-ṇeyya-gaṅgeyyo, vāneyyo-ṇeyyaka-koleyyako-ya-gammo-rassākāralopapu-🔽bbarūpāni-iya-gamiyo, udariyaṃ-“ṇiko”ti sattamyantā bhavatthe ṇiko hoti sarade bhāvo
analyzed: sattamī antāḥ ete paccayāḥ honti bahulam bhavatthe kaṇa kosi ṇara koṇeyya gaṅgeyyaḥ vāneyya uṇeyya kakoleyya koya gamma urassa ākāra lopa pu  udariyaṃ ṇikaḥ iti sattamī antā bhavatthe ṇikaḥ hoti sarade bhāvaḥ
translated: The suffix ṇeyya is added to the locative case of the words kaṇa, kosiṇara, ṇeyya, gaṅga, vana, ṇeyyaka, kola, ya, gam, and rasaka.

original: sāradiko, hemantiko.
analyzed: sāradikaḥ
translated: The suffix ṇiko is added to the locative case of the words saradi, hemanti, and ṇiko.

original: Tamassa sippaṃ sīlampaṇyampaharaṇampayojanaṃ.
analyzed: tamassa sippam sīlam paṇyam paharaṇam payojanam
translated: His craft, his virtue, his merchandise, his weapon, his purpose.

original: Paṭhamantā sippādivācakā asseti chaṭṭhatthe ṇiko hoti-vīṇāvādanaṃ sippamassa veṇiko.
analyzed: paṭhama antā sippa ādi vācakā assa iti chaṭṭha atthe hoti vīṇā vādanam sippam assa veṇikaḥ
translated: The ṇ-declension is used for craft, etc., with the sixth case ending: His craft is playing the lute, he is a lute-player (veṇiko).

original: Paṃjasukūladhāraṇaṃ sīlamassa pakaṃsukuliko, gandho paṇyamassa gandhiko, vāpo paharaṇamassa
analyzed: paṃjasukūla dhāraṇam sīlam assa pakaṃsukulikaḥ gandhaḥ paṇyam assa gandhikaḥ vāpaḥ paharaṇam assa
translated: His virtue is wearing a cloak of five strips, he is a wearer of a cloak of five strips (paṃjasukūliko). His merchandise is perfume, he is a seller of perfume (gandhiko). His weapon is a plough, he is a ploughman (vāpiko).

original: vāpiko, sataṃ payojanamassa sātikaṃ“taṃhantārahati gacchatuñchaticarati”ti dutiyantā
analyzed: vāpikaḥ satam payojanam assa dutiyantā
translated: His purpose is a hundred, he has a purpose of a hundred (sātikaṃ). “He kills, he deserves, he goes, he moves,” with the second case ending

original: bhanticcevamādisavatthesu ṇiko hoti-pakkhīnobhantiti pakkhiko-sākuṇīko-satamarahatīti
analyzed: bhant it ca ivamādi savatthesu ṇikaḥ hoti pakkhīnobhantiti pakkhi kosā kuṇī kosatam arahati iti
translated: The ṇ-declension is used for such words as these: He kills, he is a killer (pakkhīno = pakkhati).

original: sātikaṃ-paradāraṃ gacchatītipāradāriko-badare uñchatīti bādariko-dhammaṃ caratīti
analyzed: sa atikam paradāram gacchati iti pāradārikaḥ badare uñchati iti bādarikaḥ dhammam carati iti
translated: He deserves a hundred, he has a purpose of a hundred (sātikaṃ = satamarahati). He goes to another’s wife, he is a goer to another’s wife (pāradāriko = paradāraṃ gacchati). He eats jujube fruit, he is a jujube-eater (bādariko = badare uñchati).

original: dhammiko-adhammiko-“tena kataṃ kītaṃ baddhamabhiyaṅkhataṃ kasaṃsaṭṭhaṃ hataṃ hanti
analyzed: dhammika uadhammika utena katam kītam baddham abhiyaṅkhatam hatam hanti
translated: He moves in the Dhamma, he is a Dhamma-mover (dhammiko = dhammaṃ carati). He is not a Dhamma-mover, he is an un-Dhamma-mover (adhammiko = na dhammaṃ carati). “What is done, what is woven, what is bound, what is rubbed, what is sewn, what is killed, he kills;

original: jitaṃ jayati dibbati khanati tarati carati vahati jīvati”ti tatiyantā katādisvatthesu
analyzed: jitam jayati dibbati khanati tarati carati vahati kata ādi su atthesu
translated: what is conquered, he conquers; what is praised, he praises; what is dug, he digs; what is crossed, he crosses; what is moved, he moves; what is carried, he carries; what is lived, he lives,” with the third case ending

original: ṇiko hoti-kāyena kataṃvakāyikaṃ-satena kītaṃ sātikaṃ-varattāya baddhovā rattiko-ghatena🔽abhisaṅkhataṃ kasaṃsaṭṭhaṃ vā ghātikaṃ-(abhisaṅkhataṃ katābhisaṅkhāraṃ, kasaṃsaṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: ṇikaḥ hoti kāyena baddhaḥ uvā  abhisaṅkhatam kasaṃsaṭṭham vā ghātikam abhisaṅkhatam kata abhisaṅkhāram kasaṃsaṭṭham
translated: “Done with the body” is “done by the body” . “Done with the cloth” is “done with the cloth” . “Done with the rope” is “done with the rope” .🔽“Done with the basket” is “done with the basket” . “Done with the net” is “done with the net” .

original: missitaṃ)-jālena hato bhantītivā cāliko-akkhehi jitamakkhikaṃ-akkhehi jayati dibbatīti
analyzed: hataḥ bhanti iti vā cālikā uakkhehi jita makkhika akkhehi jayati dibbati iti
translated: “Done with the dice” is “done with the dice” . “Done with the dice” is “done with the dice” .🔽“Done with the axe” is “done with the axe” . “Done with the spade” is “done with the spade” . Here “done with the finger” is not found.

original: vā akkhiko-khanittiyā khanatīti khānittiko-iha nabhavati “aṅguliyā khantī”ti anabhidhānā🔽abhidhānalakkhaṇa hi tabbādi ṇadisamāsā-uḷumpena taratīti oḷumpiko-sakaṭena caratīti
analyzed: vā akkhikokhanittiyā khanati iti khānittikaḥ iha na bhavati aṅguliyā khanti iti anabhidhānā  hi tabba ādi carati iti
translated: Because of the absence of the expression “done with the finger” .🔽“Done with the raft” is “done with the raft” . “Done with the cart” is “done with the cart” .🔽“Done with the shoulder” is “done with the shoulder” . “Done with the wages” is “done with the wages” . “It comes to be for him”

original: sākaṭiko-khandhena vahatīti khandhiko-vetanena jīvatīti vetaniko-“tassa saṃvattatī”ti
analyzed: sākaṭikaḥ khandhena vahati iti khandhikaḥ vetanena jīvati iti vetanikaḥ utassa saṃvattati iti
translated: is “comes to be for him” . “It comes to be for him” is “comes to be for him” .🔽“The coming to be of what is born of mind, etc., is in me” is the second case.

original: catutthyantā saṃvattatīti ponobhaviko-“manādyapādinamo maye ce”ti dutiyokāro.
analyzed: catutthī antā saṃvattati iti maye ca iti dutiya ukāraḥ
translated: “What has come from that” is “what has come from that” .

original: Tatosambhutamāgataṃ.
analyzed: tatas sambhutam āgatam
translated: “What has come from that” is “what has come from that” .

original: Pañcamyantā sambhu tamāgatanti etesvatthesuṇiko hoti-mātito sambhutamāgataṃ vā mattikaṃ, pettikaṃ.
analyzed: pañcamī antā sambhu tam āgatanti sambhutam āgatam vā mattikam pettikam
translated: In the sense of ‘having come from’, it is ṇiko; as in mattikaṃ, pettikaṃ, ‘having come from mother, from father’.

original: Surabhito samabhutanti naviggahe.
analyzed: surabhitaḥ na viggahe
translated: In the sense of ‘having become from’, it is ṇiko; as in surabhi, ‘having become fragrant’.

original: Dissantaññepi paccayā.
analyzed: dissantaññe pi paccayā
translated: In the sense of ‘seen by’, it is ṇiko; as in paccayā, ‘seen by conditions’.

original: Vuttato’ññepi paccayā dissanti vuttāvuttatthesutiṇyo-sorabbhaṃ-“tattha vasati kaviditobhatto🔽niyutto”ti ṇiko-rukkhamūle vasatīti rukkhamūliko, loke vidito lokiko, catumahārājesu
analyzed: vutta toññe pi paccayāḥ dissanti vutta avutta tthe su ti ṇi osaḥ rabbham tattha vasati ka vi ditaḥ bhattaḥ  niyuttaḥ ti rukkha mūle vasati iti rukkhamūlikaḥ loke viditaḥ lokikaḥ catu mahārājesu
translated: In the sense of ‘seen by what is stated’, it is ṇiko; as in sorabbhaṃ, ‘seen by the statement’.🔽In the sense of ‘dwelling there’, it is ṇiko; as in rukkhamūliko, ‘dwelling at the foot of a tree’, lokiko, ‘known in the world’, catummahārājikā, ‘having the four great kings as food’.

original: bhattā catummahārājikā-dvāre niyutto dovāriko-dassoka tadaminādipāṭhā.
analyzed: bhattā catummahārājikā dvāre niyuttaḥ
translated: In the sense of ‘standing at the door’, it is ṇiko; as in dovāriko, ‘standing at the door’.🔽The following are examples of the above: dassoka, tadaminā, etc.

original: Tassidaṃ.
analyzed: tassidam
translated: This is the method.

original: Chaṭṭhiyantā idamiccasmiṃ atthe ṇiko hoti-saṅghassa idaṃ saṅghikaṃ, puggalikaṃ-“ṇe”ti
analyzed: chaṭṭhi yantāḥ idam iccasmin atthe ṇikaḥ hoti saṅghassa idam saṅghikam
translated: In the sense of ‘this’, it is ṇiko; as in saṅghikaṃ, ‘belonging to the Community’, puggalikaṃ, ‘belonging to an individual’.

original: chaṭṭhiyantā idamiccatasmiṃ attheṇe-moggallāyanassa idaṃ moggallāyanaṃ, (vyākaraṇaṃ)-sogataṃ, (sāsanaṃ).🔽Pitito bhātari reyyaṇa.
analyzed: idam icca tasmin idam moggallāyanam vyākaraṇam sogatam sāsanam  pititaḥ bhātari reyyaṇa
translated: In the sense of ‘this’, it is ṇe; as in moggallāyanaṃ, ‘of Moggallāna’, (the grammar), sogataṃ, ‘the going well’, (the Dispensation).🔽In the sense of ‘brother’, it is reyyaṇa from pitusaddā.

original: Pitusaddā tassa bhātari reyyaṇa hoti-ronu’bandho.
analyzed: pitu saddā tassa bhātari
translated: In the sense of ‘brother’, it is reyyaṇa from pitusaddā; as in ronubandho.

original: Rānubandhe’ntasarādissa.
analyzed: ra anubandha inta sa ra ādiḥ sa
translated: In the descendant, in the one with the lake inside.

original: Anto saro ādi yassāvayavassa tassa lopo hoti rānubandheti ulopo-pitu bhātā petteyyo.
analyzed: antaḥ sa raḥ ādi yassa avayavassa tassa lopaḥ hoti ra anubandhā iti bhātā petteyyaḥ
translated: The syllable beginning with the lake inside is elided, rānubandheti. Ulopo-pitu bhātā petteyyo.

original: Mātito ca haginiyaṃ cho.
analyzed: māti taḥ ca haginiyam chaḥ
translated: And in the sister from the mother’s side.

original: Mātuto ce pituto ca tesaṃ bhaginiyaṃ cho hoti-mātubhagini mātucchā-“itthiyamatvā”ti ā-evampitucchā.
analyzed: mātutaḥ ce pitutaḥ ca tesam bhaginiyam cho hoti mātu bhagini
translated: If from the mother’s side and from the father’s side, in their sister, cho is made-mātubhagini mātucchā. “Itthiyamatvā”ti ā-evampitucchā.

original: Mātāpitusvāmaho.
analyzed: mātā pitu svāmaho
translated: The mother’s and father’s master.

original: Mātāpituhi tesaṃ mātāpitusvāmaho hoti-mātu mātā mātāmahī-mātu pitā mātāmaho-pitu mātā pitāmahī-pitu pitāpi nāmaho.🔽Hite reyyaṇa.
analyzed: mātā pitu hi mātā mātāmahī mātu pitā mātāmahī pitu mātā pitāmahī pitu pitā api  hite reyyaṇa
translated: From the mother and from the father, in their mother’s and father’s master, is made-mātu mātā mātāmahī-mātu pitā mātāmaho-pitu mātā pitāmahī-pitu pitāpi nāmaho.🔽In the one related by the mother and the father, reyyaṇa.

original: Mātāpitūhi hite reyyaṇa hoti-mātu hito matteyyo, pitu hito petteyyo.
analyzed: mātā pitūhi hite hotimātu hitaḥ matteyyaḥ pitu hitaḥ petteyyaḥ
translated: From the mother and from the father, in the one related by the mother and the father, reyyaṇa is made-mātu hito matteyyo, pitu hito petteyyo.

original: Tamasya parimāṇaṃ ṇiko ca.
analyzed: tamasya parimāṇam ṇikaḥ ca
translated: That measure of it, ṇiko and ca.

original: Paṭhamantā asseti asmiṃ atthe ṇiko hoti kova tañce paṭhamantaṃ parimāṇambhavati.
analyzed: paṭhama antāḥ assa iti asmin atthe ṇikaḥ hoti paṭhama antam parimāṇam bhavati
translated: In the first, in the measure, in this meaning, ṇiko is made, if it is the first measure.

original: Doṇe parimāṇamassa doṇiko, (vīhi)-ekamparimāṇamassa ekakaṃ-dvikaṃ, tikaṃ, catukkaṃ, pañcakamiccādi.🔽Sañjātā tārakāditvito
analyzed: doṇe parimāṇam assa doṇikaḥ vīhi ekam parimāṇam assa ekakam dvikam tikam catukkam pañcakam iccādi 🔽sañjātā
translated: The measure of it is a doṇa, doṇiko, (vīhi)-the measure of it is one, ekakaṃ-two, three, four, five, etc.

original: Tārakādihi paṭhamantehi asseti chaṭṭhatthe ito hoti te
analyzed: tārakā ādihi paṭhama antehi assa iti chaṭṭha atthe i taḥ hoti te
translated: From tāraka, etc., in the first place, the affix -ita is added in the sixth case,

original: Ce sañjātā honti-tārakā sañjātā assa tārakitaṃ-(gaganaṃ)-pupchito-(rukkho).
analyzed: ce sañjātāḥ honti tārakā sañjātā assa tārakitam gaganam pupchito rukkho
translated: i.e. the locative, to denote ‘having arisen’—tārakā sañjātā honti = tārakitaṃ (the sky). Pupchitaṃ (the tree).

original: Māne matto.
analyzed: māne matto
translated: In māna, matta.

original: Paṭhamantā mānavuttito asseti asmiṃ atthe matto hoti-phakhalaṃ ummānamassa khaphalamattaṃ. Hattho parimāṇamassa hatthamattaṃ, sataṃ mānamassa satamattaṃ.
analyzed: paṭhama antā māna vuttitaḥ assa iti asmin atthe mattaḥ ummānam assa kha phala mattam hatthaḥ parimāṇam assa hattha mattam satam mānam assa sata mattam
translated: From the first māna, the affix matta is added in the sense of ‘having arisen’—phakhalaṃ ummānamassa = khaphalamattaṃ. Hattho parimāṇamassa = hatthamattaṃ. Sataṃ mānamassa = satamattaṃ.

original: Ṇe ca purisā
analyzed: ṇe ca purisā
translated: And ṇe from purisa.

original: Purisā paṭhamantā uddhamānavuttito asseti asmiṃ atthe ṇe hoti matta tagghā ca-puriso ummānamassa porisaṃ, purisamattaṃ. Purisatagghaṃ.🔽Tassa bhāvakammesu tta tā ttanaṇyaṇeyya ṇigha ṇiyā.🔽Bhavanti etasmā saddabuddhīti bhāvo saddappavatti nimittaṃ-kammaṃ kriyā-chaṭāṭhiyantā
analyzed: purisā paṭhamantā uddha māna vuttitaḥ assa iti asmin atthe ṇe hoti matta tagghā ca purisaḥ ummānam assa porisam purisa mattam purisa taggham  tassa bhāva kammesu tta tā ttana ṇya ṇeyya ṇigha ṇiyā  bhavanti etasmai
translated: From purisa in the first place, the affix ṇe is added in the sense of ‘having arisen’—puriso ummānamassa = porisaṃ, purisamattaṃ. Purisatagghaṃ.🔽In the sense of ‘state’ and ‘action’, the affixes tta, tā, ttana, ṇya, ṇeya, ṇiga, and ṇiya are added.🔽They are called ‘state’ because the idea of a word arises from it, i.e. the occurrence of a word is the cause—the action is the instrument—the sixth and seventh cases

original: bhāve kamme ca tta tādayo honti bahulaṃ-sāmaññavidhayo payogamanusārayantiti kuto
analyzed: bhāve kamme ca tta ta ādayaḥ honti bahulam sāmañña vidhayaḥ payogam anusārayanti iti kutas
translated: are the state and the action. Tta, tā, etc. are added to them. The general and particular rules follow the usage. Therefore,

original: ci dvīsukuto ci bhāve yeva-na ca sabbe sabbato honti aññatra ttatāhi-nīlassa paṭāssa
analyzed: ci bhāve ci ca sabbe sabbatas honti aññatra
translated: What is the state of the two-fold and the four-fold? Not all are so, except through that state. The state of the blue is blueness.

original: bhāvo nīlattaṃ nīlatāti guṇe bhāvo-iha guṇavasā nilasaddonīlaguṇayutte dabbe vattate
analyzed: bhāvaḥ nīlattam nīla tā ati guṇe bhāvaḥ iha guṇa vasā nila saddo nīla guṇa yutte dabbe vattate
translated: The state of a quality is here expressed by the word “blue” in the sense of the quality, in the case of the object possessing the blue quality.

original: nimittassarupānugatāñcabuddhi-evamaññatrāpi yathānurūpaṃñātabbaṃ nīlassaguṇassa bhāvo
analyzed: nimitta nīlassa guṇassa bhāvaḥ
translated: And the cognition that follows the appearance of the sign. Thus it should be known elsewhere also according to the appropriate method. The state of the blue quality is blueness.

original: nīlattaṃnīlatāti nīlaguṇajāti-gottaṃ gotāti gojāti-pācakattatti pacanakriyāsambandho-rājapurisattanti🔽rājasambandho-devadattaṃ candattaṃ sūriyattanti tadavatthāvisesa sāmaññaṃ-ākāsattaṃ
analyzed: nīla guṇa jāti gottam gottam go jāti pācakattatti pacana kriyā sambandhorāja purisattanti  rāja sambandhaḥ devadattam candattam sūriyattam ti tad avatthā avisesa sāmaññam ākāsattam
translated: The class of the blue quality is blueness. The class of the cow is got. The connection with the action of cooking is cookery. The connection with the king is kingly.🔽The particular state of that is generality. The state of space is space.

original: abhāvattanti upacaritabhedasāmaññaṃ-alasassa bhāvo kammaṃ vā alasattaṃ alasatā-ttana,🔽puthujjanattanaṃ-ṇya, cāpakalyaṃ“sakatthetī“sakatthepi-akiñcanameva ākiñcaññaṃ-ṇeyya,
analyzed: upacarita bheda sāmaññam alasassa bhāvaḥ kammam vā alasattam  puthujjana ttanaṃ ṇya cāpa kali aṃsakattha itīsakatthe pi akiñcanam eva ākiñcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañcañ
translated: The state of non-existence is the figurative difference of generality. The state of laziness is laziness.🔽The state of an ordinary person is ordinary. The state of the bow is bowness. The state of the self is selfness.

original: soceyyaṃ-ṇa, pāṭavaṃ-avaṅa-iya, naggiyaṃ-ṇi ya, porohitiyaṃ.
analyzed: naggiyaṃṇi ya porohitiyaṃ
translated: The state of the self is selfness. The state of the self is selfness. The state of the self is selfness. The state of the self is selfness. The state of the self is selfness. original: Tara tamissikiyiṭṭhātisaye.🔽Atisaye vattamānanato hontete paccayā-atisayena pāpo pāpataro, pāpatamo, pāpissiko.🔽Pāpiyo. Pāpiṭṭho-atisayantāpi atisayappaccayo-atisayena pāpiṭṭho pāpiṭṭhataro-udumbarassa🔽vikāro’vayavotvevamādiviggahe.🔽Tassa vikārāvayavesu ṇa ṇika ṇeyya mayā.🔽Pakatiyā uttaramavatthantaraṃ vikāro-chaṭṭhiyantā nāmasmā vikāre’vayave ca ṇadayo
analyzed: tara tamissikiyiṭṭha atisaye  atisaye vattamānanataḥ honti ete paccayā atisayena pāpaḥ pāpataraḥ pāpatamaḥ pāpissiko  pāpiyaḥ atisayantāpī atisaya ppaccayaḥ atisayena pāpiṭṭhaḥ pāpiṭṭhataro udumbarassa  vikāraḥ u vayavaḥ tu evamādi viggahe  tassa vikāra avayavesu mayā  pakatiyāḥ uttaram avatthantaram vikāra uccha ṭṭhi yantāḥ vikāra ivayave ca ṇa dayo
translated: and in the superlative degree.

original: honti bahulaṃ-ṇa, odumbaraṃ-(bhasmaṃ paṇṇaṃ vā)-ṇika, kappāsikaṃ-neyya, eṇeyyaṃ-maya.🔽Tiṇamayaṃ-“aññasminti” atthantarepi-gunnaṃ karisaṃ gomayaṃ.🔽Manussānaṃ samuhotvevamādiviggahe.🔽Samuhe kaṇṇaṇikā.🔽Chaṭṭhiyantā samūhe kaṇṇaṇikā honti-mānussakaṃ. Kākaṃ, āpupikaṃ-“janādīhi tā”ti samūhe tā-janānaṃ samūho janatā. Gajatā, bandhutā.
